title: Protocol for printing 3D neural tissues using the BIO X equipped with a pneumatic printhead
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Preparing the BIO X with the bioink
Timing: 15 min
This portion of the protocol includes instructions to load the BIO X printhead and complete the printer setup before printing. Proper preparation of the BIO X, including loading the printheads and using correct printer parameters, will result in production of 3D biological constructs with the highest viability and quality.
Note: Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1] demonstrates the following steps for setting up the BIO X printer with the bioink.
Set up the printhead (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1609-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. BIO X printhead and syringe setup
(A) Pieces required for printhead syringe setup.
(B) Syringe B with piece 1 (step 1a).
(C) Setup required to fill syringe (step 1b).
(D) Final set-up of syringe B (step 3).
(E) Final set-up of syringe B and printhead (step 4).
Place ‘piece 1’ (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A) into syringe B and use a thin spatula to push it to the bottom of the syringe (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
Piece 1 should be level inside the syringe and air should not be able to escape between the syringe and piece 1
Note: Syringe B and piece 1 are the empty cartridges with end and tip caps in the key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table].
Attach syringe A to syringe B via piece 2 (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).
Pour the bioink into syringe A.
Avoid creating or adding bubbles into the syringe. Problem 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1]: Air bubble formation.
A small scraper can be used to remove the remaining bioink from the conical.
Use the syringe plunger to push the bioink through piece 2 and into syringe B.
Remove piece 2 and attach piece 3 to syringe B (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]D).
Note: When printing into agarose, attach a blunt tip needle to syringe 2 instead of piece 3.

Insert syringe B into the printhead, referred to as “Tool 1” on the BIO X (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]E).
Attach syringe B to the pressure hose via the pressure connector above the printhead mount. Twist the pressure connecter to attach to syringe B.
Insert syringe B into the printhead by pushing down until the syringe is fully inserted.
    Your browser does not support HTML5 video.
  
Methods video S1. Demonstration of BIO X printer setup with bioink, related to preparing the BIO X with the bioink steps 1–4
Choosing a design and printing parameters
Timing: 15 min
Select “Bioprint” on the BIO X touchscreen.
Choose the desired model from the “Model” tab.
Shapes such as domes, cubes, and cylinders are recommended for structural integrity and printability.
Up to three 10 × 10 mm cylinder prints at 25% infill can be printed using 1 mL of bioink and 3–5 mL of crosslinker.
Optional: New designs can be uploaded to the BIO X using the USB port on the front panel of the printer.
Select the “Surface” tab and adjust the surface properties.
Choose the desired printing surface (e.g., Petri dish, well plate), size, and vendor (if applicable).
If using a well plate, select the well plate icon to set the printing pattern and desired wells.
If printing into an agarose support bath, the 6 well culture plate is recommended.
Select the “Printer” tab and adjust the printing properties.
Select the printhead being used (e.g., Tool 1 if using the printhead on the far left).
Set “Pneumatic 3 mL” as the tool type.
Set Bioink profile to “CELLINK START”.
Ensure Photo-crosslinking is set to “Off”.
Choose a desired pressure and printing speed.

When printing into an agarose support bath, a pressure of 10 kPa and a speed of 15 mm/s is suggested for the TissuePrint-HV kit.
When printing directly into a cell culture plate and pre-crosslinking, a pressure of 5 kPa and a speed of 10 mm/s is suggested when printing with TissuePrint.
Select the “Layers” tab and adjust layer properties.
Choose a desired layer profile.
“Grid Lattice” is recommended.
Select a desired infill pattern.
Set desired infill density.
Select the “Print” tab and confirm printing settings.
Press “Save” to save printing parameters, if desired.
Press “Print” to begin printing when satisfied with printing settings.
Note: For images of the BIO X setup, refer to the BIO X user manual (BIO X user manual, 2019[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]).
Calibrating the BIO X
Timing: 15 min
Select “Calibrate” at the bottom of the screen.
Choose “Manual Calibration” followed by the “Start” button.
Adjust the parameters until the needle height is the desired distance from the printing surface and press “OK”.
When printing into an agarose support bath, it is recommended to calibrate the needle tip to approximately 1 mm from the bottom of the well.
When printing directly into a cell culture plate and pre-crosslinking, it is recommended to calibrate the nozzle tip to approximately 0.1 mm from the bottom of the well.
Test pressure before beginning print to check extrusion.
Select “Pressure” from the menu.
Select pressure tab.
Hold down the “Test Flow” button to test extrusion.
If needed, adjust the pressure until the bioink extrudes at a rate of approximately 1 drop/second.
Note: Clean off the nozzle after pressure and speed testing by gently wiping with a Kimwipe™ sprayed with ethanol before printing to remove any excess biomaterial.
Press “Print”.

Note: Refer to the BIO X User Manual for further information on printing parameters and calibration protocols manual (BIO X user manual, 2019[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]).
Printing constructs directly onto a cell culture plate and pre-crosslinking
Timing: 20 min to 4 h
This step includes the instructions on how to print 3D tissue constructs directly onto cell culture plates. This method is suitable for more viscous materials that can hold their shape. Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2] presents the recommended printing parameters for this method.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1609_4.csv
Begin the print by pressing “Print”.
The printhead tip should be just above (∼0.1 mm) the cell culture plate/Petri dish.
Adjust the speed and pressure as needed to obtain a steady and even print. Problem 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3]: Lack of or inconsistent material extrusion, problem 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5]: Nozzle tip becomes clogged.
Optional: If the printed construct does not hold its shape during printing, coat the well with crosslinker before printing. Troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7]: Printed construct does not hold its shape during printing.
When the print is finished, add crosslinker to the cell culture well using a pipette. Problem 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9]: Nozzle tip leaks between prints.
Pipette crosslinker using a micropipette onto the edges of the well. Do not add crosslinker directly onto the 3D printed construct as this will distort the construct shape.
Add enough crosslinker to submerge the construct.
Let the construct sit in the crosslinker for 2–3 min or until the printed construct has sufficiently crosslinked.
Note: The printed construct is fully crosslinked when the material has gelled and holds its shape.
Note: The crosslinking time may vary depending on the bioink formulation being used.
Remove the crosslinker using a pipette.

Transfer the construct to a new (pre-coated, if applicable) cell culture plate and fill the wells with cell culture media. If printing without cells, tris-buffered saline (TBS) can be used. Preparation of TBS has been previously outlined by our lab (Abelseth et al., 2019[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]).
Optional: TBS or media can be added to the wells of the original cell culture plate instead of transferring the construct to a new plate if a pre-coated plate is not required .
Printing constructs into an agarose support bath
Timing: 20 min to 4 h
This step includes the instructions on how to print 3D tissue constructs into an agarose support bath. This method is better suited for materials and structures that do not hold their shape well directly after printing. Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3] presents the recommended printing parameters for this method.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1609_5.csv
Fill the wells of a cell culture plate with agarose gel using a pipette.
Calibrate the printhead so the needle tip sits submerged in the agarose near the bottom of the plate (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1609-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. The process of printing into an agarose support bath
(A) Needle tip is calibrated to sit submerged in the agarose support bath.
(B) The finished bioprinted construct should have distinct fibers and hold its shape.
(C) When crosslinking, the needle should circle the construct as close as possible without compromising the shape of the print.
(D) The fully crosslinked construct should hold its shape outside of the support bath and the individual fibers should be clearly visible.
Printing with a blunt tip needle is recommended.
Begin the print by pressing “Print” (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).
Adjust the speed and pressure as needed to obtain a steady and even print problem 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3]: Lack of or inconsistent material extrusion, problem 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5]: Nozzle tip becomes clogged.

A speed of 15 mm/s and pressure of 11 kPa is recommended.
Fill a syringe with crosslinker attached to a blunt tip needle.
Slowly inject crosslinker into the agarose gel surrounding the printed construct and into any empty spaces within the print (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C).
Allow it to sit for 2–3 min or until the construct has been sufficiently crosslinked. Problem 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7]: Printed construct does not hold its shape during printing.
Note: The printed construct is fully crosslinked when the material has gelled and holds its shape (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]D).
Use a spatula to remove the print and transfer to an empty well. Problem 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9]: Nozzle tip leaks between prints.
Use a wash bottle filled with TBS to rinse excess agarose off the construct.
Transfer construct to desired medium for further culturing.
Note: Phenol red was used in the images for visibility.
Printing with Alg/gel
Timing: 30 min
Table 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl4] presents the recommended printing parameters for printing with Alg/Gel or other more viscous bioinks.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1609_6.csv
Alg/Gel is viscous enough to be printed without a support bath or pre-crosslinking.
Calibrate the printhead so that the nozzle tip is approximately 0.1 mm away from the print surface.
Start the print by pressing “Print”.
A speed of 20 mm/s and a pressure of 20 kPa is recommended.
Adjust the speed and pressure as desired.
After printing, pipette 2% calcium chloride onto the print to crosslink.
Leave print in crosslinker bath for 5 min to fully crosslink.
Note: Constructs are fully crosslinked when they are firm and hold their shape. Fully crosslinked prints will expand and may double in size.
When fully crosslinked, transfer construct to a conical or petri dish using a spatula.
Store construct in TBS for up to 2 weeks.
Culturing tissue constructs
Timing: 30 min to 1 h

Thaw desired media according to manufacturer’s protocol before use.
Pipette up the old media using a 1 mL pipette tip.
Place the pipette tip at the edge of the well furthest from the construct (if possible) to avoid taking up pieces of the construct.
Pipette slowly to avoid drawing the construct into the pipette tip.
Note: It is normal for constructs to degrade overtime. If performing long-term cultures of 14 days or longer, constructs may degrade to the point that they could be sucked into the pipette. Pipetting gently and as far from the construct as possible will assist with minimizing additional degradation due to pipetting.
Repeat for necessary wells.
Add desired media to well using a serological pipette.
Add enough media to completely cover the construct.
Add media at corner of well furthest from the construct (if possible) to avoid disrupting the construct.
Media changes should be performed every day, or according to culturing protocol.
